Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Towards Ubiquitous Multimedia Sensing through Compressive Video Streaming

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
While there has been progress in recent years in solving numerous wireless sensor networking challenges, the key problem of enabling real-time quality-aware video streaming in large-scale wireless networks of resource-constrained devices is still open and largely unexplored. Existing wireless networking protocol stacks based on transmitting predictively-encoded video are computationally expensive, have limited resilience to wireless channel errors, and use available network resources inefficiently. This project is attempting a new approach based: (a) On the development of a novel wireless streaming framework for resource-constrained devices rooted in the theory of compressed sensing (CS) and (b) co-design/optimization of the video encoder and key wireless networking functionalities.

The new networked wireless streaming system being developed is referred to as Compressive Video Streaming (CVS) and has the potential to significantly reduce power consumption for a given target video quality for resource-constrained sensing devices. New network control algorithms are designed and integrated with the video encoder that, unlike TCP and TCP-friendly approaches, use the estimated received video quality as the basis for resource allocation decisions. Project implementation and extensive testing is being carried out on several experimental platforms.

The technology to be developed has the potential to strongly impact the state of the art in resource-constrained wireless video sensor networks. Important educational objectives of the program include mentoring of minority graduate and undergraduate students, and development of new interdisciplinary course materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We considered the problem of deploying a large number of simple, low-cost camera sensors in an environment of interest. The cameras have no local processing capabilities and therefore cannot execute any form of familiar video compression and coding that we enjoy in our everyday devices. The cameras are to be wireless networked in limited bandwidth conditions. Applications of this setup are important and plenty, for example dense surveillance or monitoring in extreme environments such  as underwater or outer space, multiview scene acquisition, real-time 3D visualization of the human body gastrointestinal tract/arteries, and more.

In this effort, we developed new basic mathematical foundation that allows (i) simple direct independent compressive sensing at each camera sensor, (ii) bandwidth-efficient networked communication of the sensors to one or more final destination nodes, and (iii) sophisticated joint high-quality video reconstruction at the destination node(s). The mathematical developments were first tested numerically in a simulation platform and then evaluated experimentally in true underwater data transmissions. Two principal investigators in two Universities led this research and in the process trained four Ph.D. students and two postdoctoral fellows. The mathematical developments and experimental findings from this project are published and documented in leading international archival journals and conference proceedings.
